column2: STAVE IV: THE LAST OF THE SPIRITS
column3: STAVE i v: THE LAST OF THE SPIRITS

column2: THE Phantom slowly, gravely, silently, approached.
column3: THE Phantom slowly, gravely, silently, approached.

column2: When it came near him, Scrooge bent down upon his knee; for in the very air through which this Spirit moved it seemed to scatter gloom and mystery.
column3: When it came near him, Scrooge bent down upon his knee; for in the very air through which this Spirit moved it seemed to scatter gloom and mystery.

column2: It was shrouded in a deep black garment, which concealed its head, its face, its form, and left nothing of it visible save one outstretched hand.
column3: It was shrouded in a deep black garment, which concealed its head, its face, its form, and left nothing of it visible save one outstretched hand.

column2: But for this it would have been difficult to detach its figure from the night, and separate it from the darkness by which it was surrounded.
column3: But for this it would have been difficult to detach its figure from the night, and separate it from the darkness by which it was surrounded.

column2: He felt that it was tall and stately when it came beside him, and that its mysterious presence filled him with a solemn dread.
column3: He felt that it was tall and stately when it came beside him, and that its mysterious presence filled him with a solemn dread.

column2: He knew no more, for the Spirit neither spoke nor moved.
column3: He knew no more, for the Spirit neither spoke nor moved.

column2: I am in the presence of the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come? said Scrooge.
column3: I am in the presence of the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come? said Scrooge.

column2: The Spirit answered not, but pointed onward with its hand.
column3: The Spirit answered not, but pointed onward with its hand.

column2: You are about to show me shadows of the things that have not happened, but will happen in the time before us, Scrooge pursued.
column3: You are about to show me shadows of the things that have not happened, but will happen in the time before us, Scrooge pursued.

column2: Is that so, Spirit?
column3: Is that so, Spirit?

column2: The upper portion of the garment was contracted for an instant in its folds, as if the Spirit had inclined its head. That was the only answer he received.
column3: The upper portion of the garment was contracted for an instant in its folds, as if the Spirit had inclined its head. That was the only answer he received.

column2: Although well used to ghostly company by this time, Scrooge feared the silent shape so much that his legs trembled beneath him, and he found that he could hardly stand when he prepared to follow it.
column3: Although well used to ghostly company by this time, Scrooge feared the silent shape so much that his legs trembled beneath him, and he found that he could hardly stand when he prepared to follow it.

column2: The Spirit paused a moment, as observing his condition, and giving him time to recover.
column3: The Spirit paused a moment, as observing his condition, and giving him time to recover.

column2: But Scrooge was all the worse for this.
column3: But Scrooge was all the worse for this.

column2: It thrilled him with a vague uncertain horror, to know that behind the dusky shroud, there were ghostly eyes intently fixed upon him, while he, though he stretched his own to the utmost, could see nothing but a spectral hand and one great heap of black.
column3: It thrilled him with a vague uncertain horror, to know that behind the dusky shroud, there were ghostly eyes intently fixed upon him, while he, though he stretched his own to the utmost, could see nothing but a spectral hand and one great heap of black.

column2: Ghost of the Future! he exclaimed, "I fear you more than any spectre I have seen.
column3: Ghost of the Future! he exclaimed, "I fear you more than any spectre I have seen.

column2: But as I know your purpose is to do me good, and as I hope to live to be another man from what I was, I am prepared to bear you company, and do it with a thankful heart.
column3: But as I know your purpose is to do me good, and as I hope to live to be another man from what I was, I am prepared to bear you company, and do it with a thankful heart.

column2: Will you not speak to me?"
column3: Will you not speak to me?"

column2: It gave him no reply.
column3: It gave him no reply.

column2: The hand was pointed straight before them.
column3: The hand was pointed straight before them.

column2: Lead on! said Scrooge.
column3: Lead on! said Scrooge.

column2: The night is waning fast, and it is precious time to me, I know.
column3: The night is waning fast, and it is precious time to me, I know.

column2: Lead on, Spirit!"
column3: Lead on, Spirit!"

column2: The Phantom moved away as it had come towards him. Scrooge followed in the shadow of its dress, which bore him up, he thought, and carried him along.
column3: The Phantom moved away as it had come towards him. Scrooge followed in the shadow of its dress, which bore him up, he thought, and carried him along.

column2: They scarcely seemed to enter the city; for the city rather seemed to spring up about them, and encompass them of its own act.
column3: They scarcely seemed to enter the city; for the city rather seemed to spring up about them, and encompass them of its own act.

column2: But there they were, in the heart of it; on 'Change, amongst the merchants; who hurried up and down, and chinked the money in their pockets, and conversed in groups, and looked at their watches, and trifled thoughtfully with their great gold seals; and so forth, as Scrooge had seen them often.
column3: But there they were, in the heart of it; on 'Change, amongst the merchants; who hurried up and down, and chinked the money in their pockets, and conversed in groups, and looked at their watches, and trifled thoughtfully with their great gold seals; and so forth, as Scrooge had seen them often.

column2: The Spirit stopped beside one little knot of business men. Observing that the hand was pointed to them, Scrooge advanced to listen to their talk.
column3: The Spirit stopped beside one little knot of business men. Observing that the hand was pointed to them, Scrooge advanced to listen to their talk.

column2: No, said a great fat man with a monstrous chin, "I don't know much about it, either way.

column2: I only know he's dead."

column3: When did he die? inquired another.

column2: Why, what was the matter with him? asked a third, taking a vast quantity of snuff out of a very large snuff-box. "I thought he'd never die."
column3: Why, what was the matter with him? asked a third, taking a vast quantity of snuff out of a very large snuff box. "I thought he'd never die."

column2: God knows, said the first, with a yawn.
column3: God knows, said the first, with a yawn.

column3: What has he done with his money? asked a red faced gentleman with a pendulous excrescence on the end of his nose, that shook like the gills of a turkey cock.

column3: The Phantom glided on into a street.

column3: Scrooge listened again, thinking that the explanation might lie here.

column2: They were men of business: very wealthy, and of great importance.
column3: They were men of business: very wealthy, and of great importance.

column3: He had made a point always of standing well in their esteem: in a business point of view, that is; strictly in a business point of view.

column3: How are you? said one.

column3: Well! said the first.

column3: Old Scratch has got his own at last, hey?

column2: That was their meeting, their conversation, and their parting.
column3: That was their meeting, their conversation, and their parting.

column2: Scrooge was at first inclined to be surprised that the Spirit should attach importance to conversations apparently so trivial; but feeling assured that they must have some hidden purpose, he set himself to consider what it was likely to be. They could scarcely be supposed to have any bearing on the death of Jacob, his old partner, for that was Past, and this Ghost's province was the Future.
column3: Scrooge was at first inclined to be surprised that the Spirit should attach importance to conversations apparently so trivial; but feeling assured that they must have some hidden purpose, he set himself to consider what it was likely to be. They could scarcely be supposed to have any bearing on the death of Jacob, his old partner, for that was Past, and this Ghost's province was the Future.

column2: Nor could he think of any one immediately connected with himself, to whom he could apply them.
column3: Nor could he think of any one immediately connected with himself, to whom he could apply them.

column2: But nothing doubting that to whomsoever they applied they had some latent moral for his own improvement, he resolved to treasure up every word he heard, and everything he saw; and especially to observe the shadow of himself when it appeared.
column3: But nothing doubting that to whomsoever they applied they had some latent moral for his own improvement, he resolved to treasure up every word he heard, and everything he saw; and especially to observe the shadow of himself when it appeared.

column2: For he had an expectation that the conduct of his future self would give him the clue he missed, and would render the solution of these riddles easy.
column3: For he had an expectation that the conduct of his future self would give him the clue he missed, and would render the solution of these riddles easy.

column2: He looked about in that very place for his own image; but another man stood in his accustomed corner, and though the clock pointed to his usual time of day for being there, he saw no likeness of himself among the multitudes that poured in through the Porch.
column3: He looked about in that very place for his own image; but another man stood in his accustomed corner, and though the clock pointed to his usual time of day for being there, he saw no likeness of himself among the multitudes that poured in through the Porch.

column2: It gave him little surprise, however; for he had been revolving in his mind a change of life, and thought and hoped he saw his new-born resolutions carried out in this.
column3: It gave him little surprise, however; for he had been revolving in his mind a change of life, and thought and hoped he saw his new born resolutions carried out in this.

column2: Quiet and dark, beside him stood the Phantom, with its outstretched hand.
column3: Quiet and dark, beside him stood the Phantom, with its outstretched hand.

column2: When he roused himself from his thoughtful quest, he fancied from the turn of the hand, and its situation in reference to himself, that the Unseen Eyes were looking at him keenly.
column3: When he roused himself from his thoughtful quest, he fancied from the turn of the hand, and its situation in reference to himself, that the Unseen Eyes were looking at him keenly.

column2: It made him shudder, and feel very cold.

column2: They left the busy scene, and went into an obscure part of the town, where Scrooge had never penetrated before, although he recognised its situation, and its bad repute.
column3: They left the busy scene, and went into an obscure part of the town, where Scrooge had never penetrated before, although he recognised its situation, and its bad repute.

column2: The ways were foul and narrow; the shops and houses wretched; the people half-naked, drunken, slipshod, ugly.
column3: The ways were foul and narrow; the shops and houses wretched; the people half naked, drunken, slipshod, ugly.

column2: Alleys and archways, like so many cesspools, disgorged their offences of smell, and dirt, and life, upon the straggling streets; and the whole quarter reeked with crime, with filth, and misery.
column3: Alleys and archways, like so many cesspools, disgorged their offences of smell, and dirt, and life, upon the straggling streets; and the whole quarter reeked with crime, with filth, and misery.

column2: Far in this den of infamous resort, there was a low-browed, beetling shop, below a pent-house roof, where iron, old rags, bottles, bones, and greasy offal, were bought.
column3: Far in this den of infamous resort, there was a low browed, beetling shop, below a pent house roof, where iron, old rags, bottles, bones, and greasy offal, were bought.

column2: Upon the floor within, were piled up heaps of rusty keys, nails, chains, hinges, files, scales, weights, and refuse iron of all kinds.
column3: Upon the floor within, were piled up heaps of rusty keys, nails, chains, hinges, files, scales, weights, and refuse iron of all kinds.

column2: Secrets that few would like to scrutinise were bred and hidden in mountains of unseemly rags, masses of corrupted fat, and sepulchres of bones.
column3: Secrets that few would like to scrutinise were bred and hidden in mountains of unseemly rags, masses of corrupted fat, and sepulchres of bones.

column2: Sitting in among the wares he dealt in, by a charcoal stove, made of old bricks, was a grey-haired rascal, nearly seventy years of age; who had screened himself from the cold air without, by a frousy curtaining of miscellaneous tatters, hung upon a line; and smoked his pipe in all the luxury of calm retirement.
column3: Sitting in among the wares he dealt in, by a charcoal stove, made of old bricks, was a grey haired rascal, nearly seventy years of age; who had screened himself from the cold air without, by a frousy curtaining of miscellaneous tatters, hung upon a line; and smoked his pipe in all the luxury of calm retirement.

column3: Scrooge and the Phantom came into the presence of this man, just as a woman with a heavy bundle slunk into the shop.

column3: The Phantom was exactly as it had been, but he dreaded that he saw new meaning in its solemn shape.

column2: Before I draw nearer to that stone to which you point, said Scrooge, "answer me one question.
column3: Before I draw nearer to that stone to which you point, said Scrooge, "answer me one question.

column2: Are these the shadows of the things that Will be, or are they shadows of things that May be, only?"
column3: Are these the shadows of the things that Will be, or are they shadows of things that May be, only?"

column2: Still the Ghost pointed downward to the grave by which it stood.
column3: Still the Ghost pointed downward to the grave by which it stood.

column2: Men's courses will foreshadow certain ends, to which, if persevered in, they must lead, said Scrooge.
column3: Men's courses will foreshadow certain ends, to which, if persevered in, they must lead, said Scrooge.

column2: But if the courses be departed from, the ends will change.	But if the courses be departed from, the ends will change.
column3: true

column2: Say it is thus with what you show me!"
column3: Say it is thus with what you show me!"

column2: The Spirit was immovable as ever.
column3: The Spirit was immovable as ever.

column2: Scrooge crept towards it, trembling as he went; and following the finger, read upon the stone of the neglected grave his own name, EBENEZER SCROOGE.
column3: Scrooge crept towards it, trembling as he went; and following the finger, read upon the stone of the neglected grave his own name, EBENEZER SCROOGE.

column2: Am I that man who lay upon the bed? he cried, upon his knees.
column3: Am I that man who lay upon the bed? he cried, upon his knees.

column2: The finger pointed from the grave to him, and back again.
column3: The finger pointed from the grave to him, and back again.

column2: No, Spirit!	No, Spirit!
column3: true

column2: Oh no, no!"
column3: Oh no, no!"

column2: The finger still was there.
column3: The finger still was there.

column2: Spirit! he cried, tight clutching at its robe, "hear me! I am not the man I was.
column3: Spirit! he cried, tight clutching at its robe, "hear me! I am not the man I was.

column2: I will not be the man I must have been but for this intercourse.
column3: I will not be the man I must have been but for this intercourse.

column2: Why show me this, if I am past all hope!"
column3: Why show me this, if I am past all hope!"

column2: For the first time the hand appeared to shake.
column3: For the first time the hand appeared to shake.

column2: Good Spirit, he pursued, as down upon the ground he fell before it: "Your nature intercedes for me, and pities me.
column3: Good Spirit, he pursued, as down upon the ground he fell before it: "Your nature intercedes for me, and pities me.

column2: Assure me that I yet may change these shadows you have shown me, by an altered life!"
column3: Assure me that I yet may change these shadows you have shown me, by an altered life!"

column2: The kind hand trembled.
column3: The kind hand trembled.

column2: I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year.	I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year.
column3: true

column2: I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future.
column3: I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future.

column2: The Spirits of all Three shall strive within me.
column3: The Spirits of all Three shall strive within me.

column2: I will not shut out the lessons that they teach.
column3: I will not shut out the lessons that they teach.

column2: Oh, tell me I may sponge away the writing on this stone!"
column3: Oh, tell me I may sponge away the writing on this stone!"
